Posts.Content: Mar 10, 2009 09:00PM - edited Mar 10, 2009 09:01PM by Robby My own thought is go with Memorial Sloan Kettering if they are in your plan and the NYU surgeon isn't but it sounds like the NYU surgeon is a great choice.  MSKCC has  a wide ranging team of experts -- surgeons, oncologists, radiation therapists etc.  I went there for a second opinion and was extremely impressed (albeit what they told me did not contradict what I had already been hearing from my MDs at home)-- but it's several hours away from my home and I ended up staying at home for my surgery.  I don't think one need have a surgeon who does only breast surgery but  rather one who does lots of successful breast surgery.  I returned to my home town and used a surgeon with excellent recommendations based on his breast surgery from other medical professionals as well as patients but I know he is also very good at, and performs, other kinds of surgery as well.

Posts.Content: Apr 30, 2009 12:39PM Robby wrote: Deb:  Given your questions I would definitely recommend that you see a genetic counselor and discuss genetic testing.  Seeing the counselor does not commit you to anything from what I've been told As I understand it, you would go over the pros and cons and types of genetic testing with the genetic counselor and this would help you decide whether or not you want to do the genetic testing.  If you decide you want to go ahead with it you would have to go back to your physician who would then send a blood sample to Myriad laboratories along with the reasons the testing is being recommended.  Myriad would then confirm whether or not your insurance would cover the appropriate level of testing and get back to you if you didn't have coverage so you could decide if you wanted to foot the bill.  (There are at least two tests they perform, one less extensive and less expensive than the other).

Posts.Content: Jun 4, 2009 01:21AM - edited Jun 4, 2009 01:22AM by Robby As hard as it is, I think you need to bite the bullet and be proactive --- don't be patient about your health.  We got a call right away as i recall. It was scary and some folks don't want to hear it for the first time over the phone.  However, I think it's best to learn ASAP, and then if problems, don't go to the Dr. alone.  Bring a loved one to help you sort through the details, advice.  Bring a recording tape machine and use if the physician allows it. It's all SO SO confusing at first -- and the burst of high anxiety can mask useful information transfer.  As professional and talented as one hopes one's physicians are, its our breasts and our lives and ultimately we have to learn all we can and get multiple opinions and then reach our decisions -- which may or may not be the first approach that the first MD suggests.

Posts.Content: Feb 23, 2009 11:30PM - edited Feb 23, 2009 11:32PM by Robby DonnaDio:  I  was negative for BRAC1 and 2 Ashkenazic founders Genes but they discovered a variant of uncertain significance in BRAC1.  One thing you may be able to do is have others in your family who have cancer tested for free for that variant.  Myriad has a form which tells you who can be tested. I didn't initially get the form from my oncologist but someone on the FORCE website told me about it.  As CarynRose noted, there are lots of different variants listed on FORCE, but you probably won't learn much even if you find others with it.  Only professionals can figure out the significance.  I also did a google search for my variant and found out it had an "interesting" evolutionary history, but again this didn't really tell me anything.  But getting more data for Myriad (and other clinical studies) is of value for the future and may help classify the variant at some time and may also provide insight for yourself and family members -- if the variant is ever reclassified.  The more data Myriad gets to more likely it may someday be reclassified.
